root.name: > Print Culture and the Modern World

1.name: > The Print Revolution and Its Impact

4.name: Religious Debates and Fear of Print

7.name: Reduced cost and time of book production
Shift from 'hearing public' (oral culture) to 'reading public'
Publishers printed popular content (ballads, folk tales) for the non-literate

8.name: Print enabled wide circulation of ideas and debate
Martin Luther s Ninety Five Theses (1517) reproduced widely
Led to Protestant Reformation (Luther called print 'ultimate gift of God')

17.name: Erasmus criticized the 'swarms of new books' causing 'satiety'
Roman Catholic Church imposed severe controls (Index of Prohibited Books, 1558)
Print and Dissent: Menocchio, the miller, reinterpreted Bible and was executed

9.name: Literacy rates rose (60 80% in some parts by late 18th century)
Churches set up schools for peasants and artisans

24.name: England: Penny chapbooks sold by chapmen
France: Biblioth que Bleue (low-priced, blue covers)

25.name: Scientists (Newton) and philosophers (Voltaire, Rousseau) widely printed
Mercier declared press 'most powerful engine of progress'

10.name: Created a new culture of dialogue and debate (questioning institutions)
Circulation of hostile literature (cartoons/caricatures) against monarchy
Opened up possibility of thinking differently (not direct influence)
